title: The Political Science of Open Science
content:
This article summarises the results of a round-table discussion at the Science|Business annual conference held in Brussels on 4-5 February 2026. We are grateful for the engagement of other participants whose ideas have shaped what is presented here.

title: Opening Research Information by Law?
content:
For over two decades, the open access movement has advocated for—and delivered on—the goal of making the published results of research available without financial barriers.

Building on this, the drive for open science has expanded this focus, recognising that full openness goes beyond publishing research findings to encompass the full range of outputs generated throughout the research process, including data, methodologies, and more.

title: Rights? Wrong! 4 Problems That Tougher Copyright Law Won’t Solve
content:
Copyright was created as a means of ensuring that once someone had created a work—originally a book but now also a song, picture, or some other form of creation—they had the benefit of a principle that applied to the control of its distribution and use. At least if people wanted to buy it, they would then need to pay, creating an income stream for the creator or whoever else held the rights.

It has given rise to business models that, as its advocates argue, represent a noteworthy share of the economy—on average an estimated 4% across Europe, depending on how broadly the creative sector is defined. title: Public Domain Day 2026: Calling the Plumber Before the Taps Run Dry
content:
1 January each year marks the moment when a new wealth of materials (books, songs, art and other forms of expression) loses the protection offered by copyright against actions like copying, distribution, translation, or more by entering the public domain. Throughout the month, including today in Brussels, events are organised both to celebrate this and to discuss current and emerging issues.

title: Looking Ahead: Cyprus’ EU Presidency, January-June 2026
content:
As of 1 January, Cyprus took up the Presidency of the European Union’s Council of Ministers for six months.

title: Why Reform Matters: Early Takeaways from the Commission’s Report on Distance Education and Research
content:
This week, the European Commission published a new research report, commissioned following a request from the European Parliament, and produced by a consortium led by Visionary Analytics.

The Parliament’s original request, developed in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, was to examine how well the copyright system had enabled education and research to continue remotely.
